title: letters to the editor week 30
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 30/07/18, 9:27 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to read more?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Sir,As usual with Councillor Redman, he was so desperate to berate the SNP in his letter published in the July 20 edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser that he is unable to see the hypocrisy of his own stance.He talks of &#8216stealth taxes&#8217 hitting &#8216the most vulnerable people in our society, particularly elderly people living alone&#8217.His accusation of &#8216taking their eye off the day job&#8217 begs the question as to where he was when the Tory government introduced its bedroom tax &#8211 a tax on those who needed an extra room for live-in carers, a tax on grandparents who wanted to have their grandchildren to stay for weekends and at holiday times a tax on widows with sons and daughters in the armed forces expected to sleep on a sofa when home on leave.A disgraceful tax which the SNP government abolishedDavid Hay, MinardSir,It was superb to once again meet up with locals in Whitehouse and across west Kintyre. As well as hearing about numerous problems with local road repairs I also listen to concerns about slow internet speed with some areas lagging behind others when it comes to getting access to superfast broadband.I heard similar concerns when I attended the latest West Kintyre Community Council meeting. As ever, I will looking into every issue brought to my attention by local residents across my council ward.After travelling back to Islay I checked up on the state of road repairs across the island. Some progress has been made in many areas like the Hospital Road in Bowmore and Mansefield Road in Port Ellen. The potholes in Port Askaig that I had been telling our roads department about have been filled in.After calling and emailing around about the large and dangerous potholes at An Creagan Place in Port Charlotte, I have been informed that the road in this area is not the responsibility of Argyll and Bute Council. It belongs to ACHA, and since obtaining this information I spoke in person to the very helpful and hard-working staff at the Bowmore ACHA office and asked them to fill in these potholes.Aside from road concerns on Islay, quite a number of my fellow Ileachs have mentioned lack of bed spaces in Islay&#8217s hospital. Being an island community obviously means that transferring more and more patients to the mainland is hardly ideal.The consensus from my constituents who I have been in contact with is that the number of beds in Islay&#8217s hospital is not enough. I have contacted NHS Highland to voice my constituents anger about this situation.Cllr Alastair Redman, Isle of IslaySir,The Marine Conservation Society (MCS) is seeking volunteers to clean up Scotland’s beaches in the 25th anniversary Great British Beach Clean from September 14-17.Volunteers also record the litter they find, and this has really helped change policy and behaviours.Last year 1,588 volunteers in Scotland took part, cleaning 111 beaches in four days. A staggering 491.4 pieces of litter were found for every 100 metres cleaned, a seven per cent rise on the amount recorded during 2016&#8217s event.The fight to stop the plastic tide has only just started and we need everyone to take part now more than ever. We need the evidence from these surveys to highlight the action we all need to take for the sake of Scotland’s seas.To volunteer visit www.mcsuk.org/greatbritishbeachclean or call 01989 566017.Catherine Gemmell, MCS Scotland Conservation Officer.Sir,The Tories’ hypocrisy on MoD wages has been exposed – after it was revealed that around 220 staff in Scotland don’t receive the Real Living Wage, just days after the Tories topped up the pay of some of the best paid MoD staff.An MoD Freedom of Information response revealed that 220 staff in Scotland earn below the Real Living Wage of £8.75 an hour – yet they are not in line to receive any pay boost from their employers. The Tories’ policy is set to cost around £4 million – yet boosting the wages of those receiving less than the real living wage would cost, at most, under £400,000.This smacks of utter hypocrisy from the Tories, after their comments of recent days regarding pay for forces personnel.What the Tories are choosing to overlook is the immense benefits service personnel have living in Scotland, like free prescriptions and university tuition fees for their children.  And it’s only those earning above £33k who pay a fraction more.If they are so concerned with equality – why aren’t they ensuring that all MoD staff are paid the living wage?Boosting the incomes of the lowest paid MoD staff could cost the Tories less than a tenth of what they are spending to top up higher incomes – yet once again, for people on lower incomes they are not prepared to lift a finger.The Tories’ double standards know no bounds – it’s one rule for the elite and another for the rest.Brendan O&#8217Hara, MP for Argyll and Bute

title: ayrshire motorists urged park appropriately
story: NewsAyrshire motorists urged to park appropriately at Ayr and Crosshouse HospitalsDrivers warned to keep grounds as safe as possible for patients, visitors and staffShare&nbspByGary Fanning10:00, 29 JUL 2018NewsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHealth bosses were this week urging motorists to park ‘appropriately’ after complaints about parking chaos at Ayr Hospital. NHS Ayrshire &amp Arran this week appealed for drivers to help to keep the grounds as safe as possible for patients, visitors and staff. The car parks at University Hospitals Ayr and Crosshouse have designated short and long stay areas which are clearly signposted. The short stay car parks have a time limit of three hours and the long stay car parks are for people who need to park for longer than three hours. When the car parking scheme was first implemented, there was a significant improvement in parking behaviours. However, this has not continued. John Wright, director for corporate support services, said: “Over the past few years we have carried out surveys and audits of the car parks at University Hospitals Ayr and Crosshouse and created more than 400 new spaces across both sites. However, we have now reached the limit of the number of new car parking spaces we can build. We are, therefore, asking for help from members of the public. “We need to make sure that we all play our part in parking appropriately and safely in all of our car parks across all of our sites. This will help traffic to flow better, reduce the risk of accidents and ensure that we comply with health and safety regulations.” Mr Wight is urging motorists to: park only in a designated parking bay and do not park on footpaths, or at road junction He urged drivers notto park in disabled parking spaces if you do not have a blue badge Mr Wright said people can help reduce congestion at car park by travelling to the hospital by public transport or car share. He added: “We know that parking is challenging on our sites, particularly at University Hospitals Ayr and Crosshouse. “However, we are limited to the number of spaces we have and this is why we are urging the public and our staff to help us and to park appropriately. We will also be looking at other ways of reducing the volume of traffic on our sites at particular times of the day.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr HospitalUniversities and CollegesCrosshouseAyr

title: health inspectors found heavily contaminated
story: NewsHealth inspectors have found “heavily contaminated” equipment in Ayrshire’s maternity theatreProbe uncovered suspected blood contamination at hospitalShare&nbspByStuart Wilson07:00, 31 JUL 2018NewsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHealth inspectors have found “heavily contaminated” equipment in Ayrshire’s maternity theatre. A probe also uncovered suspected blood contamination on the shoes of staff at Crosshouse Hospital. The shock investigation, carried out by Healthcare Improvement Scotland in May, included A and E, the maternity inpatient ward and theatre department, and the medical high dependency unit. Examiners said they “observed good compliance with hand hygiene”. “This included medical, nursing and domestic staff,” they added. But the report said that maternity theatre staff “appeared confused” about infection prevention and control audits, which was raised with senior managers. Concerns were also raised regarding suspected blood found on staff’s shoes and contaminated equipment in the maternity theatre and changing rooms. It comes just 12 months after a government-commissioned report into the “unnecessary” deaths of six babies at the hospital which criticised staff shortages. The latest hygiene report stated: “We were told it is the responsibility of each member of staff to clean these, however, it was recognised this had been difficult to implement with some staff groups. “In the maternity theatres, two positional pieces were heavily contaminated on the inside covers. “This equipment is used to provide support and stability to patients during their procedures. “We were told these were removed immediately and replacements were ordered.” Inspectors said they were aware of “good segregation of domestic and clinical waste”. But their report added: “In the maternity theatres, clinical waste was not stored locked awaiting uplift. “We also identified a similar issue in the wards. This could allow unauthorised access to clinical waste.” Alastair Delaney, from Healthcare Improvement Scotland said: “A good standard of cleaning was found generally and it was noted that considerable improvements have been made to cleanliness of equipment in the emergency department since our last inspection. “However, to improve care, NHS Ayrshire and Arran should ensure theatre departments are maintained so they can be effectively cleaned to provide a safe environment for patients.” Hazel Borland, nurse director for the health board, said: “We fully accept these findings. “The HEI inspection was valuable in helping us identify areas where we need to improve and our staff found the visit to be informative and useful. “We are pleased the inspection team observed that there is a good standard of cleaning and cleanliness generally. “We have an action plan in place to ensure the requirements and recommendations highlighted are addressed and we will ensure we continue to provide high standards of care and hygiene throughout our healthcare settings.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnCrosshouse HospitalAyr

title: kilmarnock man who lifelong alcohol
story: NewsKilmarnock man who has had lifelong alcohol struggle shares heartbreaking story and says: "I don't want my grandson seeing me drunk every day"At his worst Andrew from Kilmarnock could drink a bottle of vodka per day, on top of 10 or 15 pints of beer.Share&nbspByDavid Wren12:25, 27 JUL 2018NewsAndrew has struggled with drink his whole life (picture posed by model)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“I’ve got a daughter and a grandson, I don’t want them seeing me drunk everyday,” says Andrew, who has struggled with alcohol for most of his adult life. At his worst, the 59-year-old from Kilmarnock – who has asked for his surname to be withheld – could drink a bottle of vodka per day, on top of 10 or 15 pints of beer. His situation was desperate, with the alcohol numbing the pain of crippling mental health issues he has suffered from for years. Andrew spoke out after it was revealed in last week’s Kilmarnock Standard that there were 48 alcohol-related deaths at Crosshouse Hospitalin 2017/18, an increase from 38 in the previous year. Illnesses and injuries related to alcohol which have been treated at the facility have also gone up, with NHS Ayrshire and Arran aiming to tackle the problem.  Andrew said: “I’ve been drinking repeatedly for 25 years. I used to drink a litre of vodka a day and roughly four litres per week. “I’d maybe have 10 or 15 pints of beer a day as well. I sought help from various organisations which didn’t help. “I’ve been struggling with my mental health over the years too. The main reason I’ve been hitting the drink is because of my mental health and I can’t get any help.” His battles with drink and mental health have led Andrew to dark places and he has attempted suicide twice. A chaotic lifestyle where he has had brushes with the law over the years also played a part in his mindset, as well as an incident in his late teens where a gun was put to his head. The terrifying ordeal, Andrew says, “wasted my head” and he continues to have flashbacks. It started off his spiralling issues with anxiety and depression which have plagued his life and repeatedly led him back to alcohol. After one suicide attempt, Andrew said that he was told to quit his vodka habit and did so overnight. But the consequences of going cold turkey led to a mild stroke the following day. Battles with his health have continued over the years, meaning he is now on 17 tablets a day just to help his body function. Andrew doesn’t consider himself an alcoholic, but admits he has struggled with drink for most of his life. He also claims that he’s struggled to access help for his mental health issues. He said: “I’ve been to various organisations and they hunt me. “They take the name and address, say they’ll contact you – then nothing.  “So I go to drink and that solves the mental health problems. “But it actually triggers it. Sometimes it eases me and it’s a bit back to front. “These mental health organisations have no money, no funds and the NHS is in a terrible state. “The only people I can rely on are the Ayrshire Council on Alcohol down in Ayr. “I’m not an alcoholic, I’ve just got a problem with drink. “I don’t like being called an alcoholic, I’m just a normal guy that needs help.” The Ayrshire Council on Alcohol have helped him work on his problem with drink. Although on a long road to recovery, Andrew’s drinking has decreased. But, even though the alcohol counselling helps, he admits he’s desperate to tackle his mental health issues. He said: “I’m down to drinking four days a week now, before I would have been seven. The ACA have helped me, I would recommend them to anybody. “They explain the circumstances and give you a target to achieve over a period. They don’t want you to come off of it straight away. “It maybe goes from seven days to five and so on.” He continued: “In a day I’ll maybe drink 15 pints. That used to be every day but now I’ve cut it down to four. “It’s a lot of beer. It’s very hard to say the effect the alcohol has on me. “My main issue is the mental health, the anxiety and depression, my head’s wasted.” Having been in the habit of drinking every day for so long, Andrew removes himself from the dangers of binging when his days away from alcohol come around.   He goes on day trips across Ayrshire to keep him away from the lure of  the pub, which Andrew admits he would struggle to resist if he was just hanging around Kilmarnock town centre.  Although he lives himself, Andrew says he doesn’t drink in the house and bottles of booze stay untouched in his home. The social aspect of the pub, he says, is the lure for him as he seeks the company it brings. Andrew believes he can quit drink – but admits his mental health constantly brings him back to square one as he looks for a life away from alcohol. He says the ACA is saving his life with their support and he hopes continued work with the organisation can help him to live a healthy life. “At times I was just desperate, thinking ‘why live?’” said Andrew. “But I’ve got a grandson now, a daughter, so it gives me something to look forward to in the future. “Hopefully one day I can come off the drink. “Never say never – it’s my ambition.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrKilmarnockAlcoholCrosshouse

title: mayboles christmas celebrations in jeopardy
story: NewsMaybole's Christmas celebrations in jeopardyThe community association organises a Christmas lights switch-on ceremony, as well the summer gala day.Share&nbspByAyrshire Post11:18, 25 JUL 2018NewsMaybole Christmas lights switch on (Image: David Kiltie)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe town’s Christmas celebrations will be in the ice box this year after a community group agreed to freeze itself for six months. Maybole Community Association will not meet again until January, by which time the festive fun will be over. The group organises a Christmas lights switch-on ceremony, as well the summer gala day. But members could not form a committee at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM). A statement issued after the meeting states: “Following the EGM held by Maybole Community Association on Thursday, July 12, 2018, regrettably no one came forward at the meeting prepared to be an office bearer, knowing that the present committee were standing down. “The decision was therefore made at the meeting for all activities of the association to be frozen and put on hold for a minimum period of six months and a maximum of 12 months and will be reviewed again at that time. “No business will be conducted during that timescale. This decision means that there will be no Christmas lights switch-on and potentially no gala next year.” Outgoing chairperson Senga Mason had been in her role for three years and took over after a similar committee crisis.  She said: “People didn’t come forward for the main committee roles and there’s far greater pressures on people’s time now than there was 40 years ago.” Mrs Mason’s connection to the group, founded in 1975, goes back to 1978. Maybole Gala Days in days gone by featured lorry floats and impressive bunting displays across the High Street. But Mrs Mason pointed out: “Health and safety rules meant the end of using lorries, which in any case are normally needed 24/7 by operators. “Even for simple things like bunting you need permits and a cherry picker to put it up. “Rules are in place for a reason and we have to abide by them.” Community association members are also upset at what they saw as unfair criticisms made on social media following this year’s Maybole Gala Day on June 9. A switch-on ceremony in Maybole can only now be saved if another group of volunteers steps forward. If the community association decides to wind up in January its assets - cash, tables, chairs and gazebos - would be dispersed to other groups in the town.

title: monster mystery strange carcass washes
story: NewsMonster mystery as strange carcass washes ashoreAnd reader Brian Cassells snapped this image of the creature from the deep.Share&nbspByAyrshire Post13:30, 27 JUL 2018NewsThe sea creature remains photographed by reader Brian Cassells (Image: Brian Cassells)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA strange 20ft carcass was washed up on the shore, south of Greenan Castle, writes Edwin Lawrence. And reader Brian Cassells snapped this image of the creature from the deep. “I’d never seen anything like it before,” said Brian, who was out walking with wife Julie and their two small pet dogs. “At first I thought it must be part of a fishing net, or some kind of rope from a boat. “But then, looking closer at it, it was more like a giant version of those little bones you see when you open a tin of salmon.” Aircraft mechanic Brian, 55, also noted what looked like the remains of a large fin on the sea monster. The carcass was in the water when he first spotted it. But he got a better look on a return walk, two days later. “It had started to break up a bit,” said Brian. “But I got a chance to pace out a rough measurement on dry land.  “And I reckon it was at least 20 feet long.” The Post passed on Brian’s pictures to Girvan-based David Bova, a retired Marine Scotland scientist. David, 61, said: “The images suggest the remains of a basking shark. “Shark skeletons are cartilage rather than bone, and this looks to be the case here.” David explained that basking sharks tend to be seasonal visitors to the Firth of Clyde, feeding on plankton bloom. The gentle giants can grow to over 30ft long, and weigh several tons. “I haven’t seen one so far this summer,” said David, who is regularly out on the waters around Ailsa Craig. Brian was interested to hear David’s opinion, and agrees with his view that the skeleton was more like cartilage than bone. “We kept Daisy (Bichon Frise) and Millie (Cavachon) well away anyway!” he joked.

title: outsiders ayr united tipped follow
story: NewsOutsiders Ayr United tipped to follow in footsteps of 70s glory side, says Jim McSherryJim McSherry reckons the heroes of yesteryear can have their past glories repeated by the current crop.Share&nbspByMike Wilson16:04, 20 JUL 2018NewsAyr United squad picture taken in 1975 (Image: user submitted)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey’re 66/1 rank outsiders to win the Championship – but Jim McSherry can recall when Ayr were the same price to win the first-ever Premier Division. And United proved that underdogs can upset the odds by finishing sixth and leaving Aberdeen, Dundee United, Dundee and St Johnstone in their wake. It was a stunning effort but McSherry, who was signed by Ally MacLeod on a free from Kilmarnock, reckons Ayr can once again confound the pundits and enjoy a great season. United kick off the league at home to Partick Thistle on August 4 and midfielder turned publican McSherry expects them to be up for the challenge. He said: “Consolidation should be the aim but there is no reason why Ayr can’t rise again and enjoy the good times that we enjoyed in the 70s.” An old team picture that surfaced in McSherry’s Wee Windaes got punters rewinding the years and reliving past glories. It was taken at the start of season 1975-76 and showed Ayr in their change kit of Barcelona strips. Proudly standing tall are, back row – Davie Wells, Alex McAnespie, Ally MacLean, Hugh Sproat, Rikki Fleming, John Murphy. Middle row – Alex Ingram, Gerry Phillips, Johnny Graham, Johnny Doyle, Hugh Cameron, Jim McSherry. Front row – John Dickson, Danny MacDonald, Davie McCulloch.   Jim recalled: “No one could work out why the team weren’t in their usual black and white if it was an official  team picture.  “We were also puzzled why there were 15 players in it, including two goalkeepers. “Then one of my regulars, Stephen Robb, came up with the answer – it was taken before a pre-season friendly.  “We wore it in a 7-2 defeat at home to Celtic and it was never seen  again. I think it was binned as a bad omen.  “These were good times at Ayr and the team was loaded with some great players. “We were the only part-time team in the Top Ten and were quoted at 66/1, which seemed about right given the teams we were up against. “I remember Ally signing me on the wall at Central Station and then telling me to look out my passport. “He told me ‘You’re going on tour to Canada next week’. It was quite a start to my Ayr career.” Only three months into that season, Ally was lured to Aberdeen and replaced at the helm by Alex Stuart who quickly appointed McSherry as captain. Ayr sealed safety with a last-day 2-1 win over Motherwell, who were bossed by Willie McLean and Craig Brown. Gerry Phillips got a dramatic late winner to spark euphoric scenes at a packed Somerset. The second season of top-flight football saw Ayr again more than hold their own.  They finished eighth in the table on 30 points, three ahead of Hearts and a distant 13 more than rock-bottom  rivals Kilmarnock.  Season 1977-78 marked Ayr’s third campaign in the top flight, a remarkable achievement considering they stayed part-time. Robert Connor, Ian McAllister, Derek McCutcheon and Iain Sim were called up from Ayr United Boys’ Club. But Ayr were always up against it and their life in the Premier League ended when they finished second-bottom on 24 points and were relegated along with Clydebank. Now as a new league season beckons with renewed optimism and a totally full-time structure, it’s time to dream again. Bring it on!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnCraig BrownAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: partick thistle v ayr united
story: NewsPartick Thistle v Ayr United: Top of the group deciderThe Honest Men head to Firhill today knowing that a win will be enough to top the group and put them into the hat for the knockout stages.Share&nbspByLochlin Highet10:45, 25 JUL 2018NewsAyr United manager Ian McCall (Image: SNS Group)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIan McCall insists his side will do everything they can to qualify for the last 16 of the Betfred Cup. Ayr United head to Firhill to take on Partick Thistle today knowing that a win will be enough to top the group and put them into the hat for the knockout stages. The Honest Men beat Morton 3-1 in their first group game before beating Albion 2-0 on Saturday. McCall’s side then hammered Stenhousemuir 5-0 at Somerset Park on Tuesday. And McCall, who will head to his old stomping ground on Saturday, said: “It’s a good game against a team in the same league as us. “They are fancied to be challenging for the league title, so it will be a good gauge for us to see where we are at. “I don’t think the game will have any similarities to the league opener though, but if there is a place up for grabs in the last 16 then we are going to go for it.” The Betfred Cup format has come under scrutiny from a number of players and managers involved in the game.  But McCall has gone against the grain and offered his support for the group stage style. He said: “I think it’s good and I like it. “I like the games that actually mean something, rather than meaningless friendlies which I hate. “With this format it means you only need three pre season friendlies. “And we have done well in the opening couple of games so that momentum will hopefully stick with us going into the league campaign.” Ross Docherty has been back in full training for the past week, with Chris Higgins set to join back up with the squad next week. •The Ayr United open day will take place this Sunday from 12pm. Fans are welcome to join the party at Somerset where they can meet their heroes amidst a whole host of fun events. The players and managers will be there along with a Stagedoor BBQ, Mancini’s ice cream and a kids v adults match to soak in, plus plenty of more fun activities.

story: NewsThieving females raid senior citizen's homeDonna Graham, 34, and Lynsay Cooper, 35, both admit the charge.Share&nbspByAyrshire Post12:42, 30 JUL 2018NewsAyr Sheriff Court (Image: Ayrshire Post)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA thieving pair of females broke into a pensioner’s house and stole his medication, cigarettes and coins. Donna Graham, 34, and Lynsay Cooper, 35, both admit the charge. But only Graham turned up at Ayr Sheriff Court, and a warrant was issued for Cooper’s apprehension. Lawyer Ian Gillies pleaded guilty on Cooper’s behalf to a break-in charge against her. He said he was unable to explain her absence from court. The charge admitted by the duo says they broke into the home of a man, then aged 66, in Prestwick’s Adamton Road South, on October 10 last year.  Graham admitted an additional charge of breaking into the home of a 93-old man in Ayr’s Elba Court, also on October 10 last year. This charge states that she stole around &pound400 in cash from the man. The court heard that Graham, formerly of an address in Ayr’s Russell Drive, now lives in Prestwick. Coopers’ address was given as Murray Gardens in Maybole. The case was adjourned until August 16, when the pair are expected to appear together for sentence.

title: bbc-presenter-chris-packham-surveys-borders-estate
story:
TV presenter Chris Packham visited Tweeddale this week to carry out a healthcheck on local wildlife.
The naturalist, who is best known for presenting BBC&rsquos Springwatch, headed to the Glenlude estate near Traquair as part of his &lsquobioblitz&rsquo tour.
The aim of the 10-day campaign is to investigate which species are under threat and to raise money for local projects working on the conservation and restoration of habitats.
Along with Chris and his specialist team, dozens of John Muir Trust volunteers, who manage the site, identified 388 species during an intensive survey of the 150-hectare site.
Those involved included scientific experts on moths, bats, lichens, dragonflies, sedge grasses, birds and other species.
The presenter said: &ldquoThe tour is about measuring the health of our landscapes.
&ldquoIt is time conservationists came together, unified to think about the bigger picture. We&rsquore not going to agree on everything, but if we agree on 60 or 70 per cent that&rsquos enough. There are things we can do today that will have an impact tomorrow.
Representatives from Glasgow-based drug and alcohol recovery charity Phoenix Futures Scotland also took part in the survey. The charity has a six-year connection with Glenlude, where participants in its Recovery Through Nature programme have planted and nurtured a new native woodland.
Karen Purvis, the John Muir Trust&rsquos local land manager, said: &ldquoWe were delighted to welcome Chris and his team to Glenlude and to assist with this fantastic project to get a better understanding of the state of nature across the UK.
&ldquoWe do our own regular monitoring work focusing on specific species but we&rsquove found this comprehensive snapshot incredibly helpful &ndash and we&rsquove already discovered several new species we were unaware existed here.
&ldquoIt also gives us a great benchmark to measure progress on the estate, where we have a long-term project to bring back native woodland and its associated wildlife.

title: new-trails-on-offer-in-cardrona-forest
story:
THREE new walking trails have been opened in the heart of the Tweed Valley.
The waymarked routes in Cardrona Forest are part of a &pound50,000 investment by Forest Enterprise Scotland to help boost tourism.
The first &ndash Pen View Trail &ndash has been categorised as &lsquoeasy&rsquo and is 1.7 miles long.
The second &lsquoeasy&rsquo route &ndash Fergus&rsquos Trail &ndash is 2.4-miles through woodland to discover Cardrona Tower. And the &lsquomoderate&rsquo four-mile Pikes Knowe Trail shows off Cardrona Tower and the Iron Age fort Castle Knowe.
Katie Jarvis, recreation forester with Forest Enterprise Scotland told us: &ldquoCardrona Forest is a gem of a forest just outside Peebles and is especially a favourite for walkers who want a quieter and more relaxed time.
&ldquoIt&rsquos very popular with local people but also visitors from further afield.
&ldquoThe trails range from over a mile long to four miles in length so there&rsquos a bit of variety.
&ldquoYou can take an easier walk for around an hour, right up to a longer leg stretcher of two hours if you have more time.

title: wilton-lodge-is-flying-flag-for-borders-parks
story:
HAWICK&rsquos Wilton Lodge Park has become the first in the Borders to be awarded a coveted Green Flag, following its &pound3.64 million revamp.
The 43-hectare park is only the second in the south of Scotland to pick up the award, which is the benchmark standard for publicly accessible parks and green spaces across the UK and around the world.
Judges acknowledged the work carried out to improve the park as part of a regeneration scheme, which is due to be completed this summer.
Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund and Scottish Borders Council, the face-lift has delivered a number of new facilities including a play-park, Zandra Elliot Bandstand, caf&eacute and the McLaren Bridge.
There have also been improvements to the walled garden, waterfall walk and Hawick Museum, alongside the busy summer events programme which saw Hawick favourites Scocha play to more than 600 people earlier this month.
There has also been a number of other works carried out to the various shelters and memorials within the park, including the Cenotaph, Boer War Memorial, MacNee Fountain, Jimmie Guthrie Memorial, Laurie Shelter and Henderson Shelter.
Thanks to &pound100,000 from SUSTRANS, improvements were made to the surface of footways, lighting and signage, along with a further &pound20,000 from Smarter Choices, Smarter Placed fund to promote cycling.
Tree planting and improvements to the park&rsquos main entrance, the Common Riding ceremonial area and Gilbert Davidson Fountain are also part of the regeneration project. And a total of 27 interpretation boards have been installed this summer to help visitors navigate around the park&rsquos various features.
The park was developed in the late 19th century from a former private estate.
Councillor Sandy Aitchison (Ind), Scottish Borders Council&rsquos executive member for neighbourhoods and locality services, said: &ldquoThis award is a huge honour for Hawick and the Scottish Borders, being the very first park or green space in our region to receive Green Flag status.
&ldquoThe award has recognised the stunning landscape of the park and the wide variety of new facilities provided through the regeneration project, which has been funded by the council and its various partners.
Pete Leonard, operations director at Keep Scotland Beautiful, said: &ldquoIt is great to see a newly regenerated site, which has been supported by the Heritage Lottery Funding, added to the list of awarded parks.
&ldquoWe are very proud of all Scotland&rsquos Green Flag Award parks and this year we have had a number of new parks receive their Green Flag.
&ldquoThis is clearly recognition for everyone&rsquos efforts in helping to make their local open space a greener, cleaner and healthier place to live, work and play.

title: ben-saddles-up-to-cycle-coast-to-coast-in-one-day
story:
A PEEBLES man is saddling up this weekend to cycle coast-to-coast across Scotland in a day.
Ben Glasgow will join riders from Edinburgh and South Ayrshire in a charity cycle ride from Prestwick, on the west coast to Berwick.
The 37-year-old, who aims to complete his 140-mile journey on Saturday, will travel through Ayrshire, Lanarkshire, Peeblesshire and across the Borders.
The ride will set off at 6am, and aims to pass through Peebles&rsquo Tweed Green between 1.15pm and 1.30pm.
The epic event aims to raise money for three causes &ndash blood cancer charity DKMS Alzheimer Scotland and Cash for Kids.
The former Peebles and Edinburgh Northern &lsquoGents&rsquo (over 35s) rugby player started cycling in 2015 after a knee injury put a halt to his regular appearances on the pitch.
And Ben, who works for the Scottish Government, is calling on Peebleans to show their support on Saturday and get involved, as he takes on his longest-ever bike ride.
He said: &ldquoAdding another 50 per cent on to the longest ride I&rsquove ever done in one day will be quite a challenge.
&ldquoI&rsquom not exactly of an aerodynamic build, and the route we&rsquore taking across the width of Scotland features some pretty testing terrain to climb up and over on the best of days for bigger units like me &ndash let alone if the weather conditions and wind decide to conspire against us.
&ldquoI&rsquom looking forward to it though, and continuing to raise much-needed funds for a variety of great charitable causes. Anyone from Peebles who wants to join us for any length of the the second half of the trip from Tweed Green in Peebles over to Berwick Upon Tweed would be most welcome &ndash estimated departure from Peebles is around 1.15pm/1.30pm.
To make a donation, go to justgiving and search for &lsquoBen Glasgow&rsquo to find the three separate fundraising pages for DKMS, Alzheimer Scotland and Cash for Kids.

title: ooh-la-la-celebration-francaise-a-walkerburn
story:
PART of Walkerburn turned French last Saturday &ndash to celebrate Bastille Day.
The village bowling and p&eacutetanque club hosted an open day &ndash which featured a barbecue and picnic &ndash to mark what is known as La F&ecircte Nationale.
It commemorates the storming of the Bastille in Paris in 1789 and the forming of the French Federation in 1790.
And to in keeping with the theme, the club was decked out in blue, white and red bunting, with two make-shift poles flying tricouleurs and the Saltire.
Locals got into the spirit of things by dressing in striped t-shirts and eating baguettes, brie, quiche, croissants as well as some Scottish fare.
There was also an opportunity to try out p&eacutetanque &ndash which originated in Provence.
As well as club members, there were visitors from Melrose and Gala, Peebles, Moffat and even one new player from Japan.
Club secretary Bruce Macalister said the day was a huge success.
He added: &ldquoAs a club we are keen to increase awareness of the game in the area and invite anyone interested in having a go to come along on Friday afternoons from 2pm.
&ldquoWe have spare sets of boules for both adults and children and these times can be adapted should the need arise.
&ldquoThe p&eacutetanque pistes are adjacent to the bowling green, just across the River Tweed on Caberston Road (opposite the Caberston Coffee Shop).
For further information please contact Bruce at brucemacalister@hotmail, or phone 01896 870620.

title: innerleithen-gearing-up-for-international-festival
story:
THE line-up has been announced for the Beyond Borders International Festival, which is returns to Innerleithen next month.
Former CIA operative Valerie Plame, historian William Dalrymple and authors Magnus Linklater, Richard Holloway and Stuart Kelly will be among the headliners at Traquair House on August 25 and 26.
And Scotland&rsquos bestselling female music artist Barbara Dickson will also be on hand to perform.
The festival will feature a host of local and international artists, writers, journalists, politicians, and diplomats for a weekend of panel debates and discussions, spoken word, music, exhibitions, film, walks, and bike rides.
The Main Tent Programme features sessions with the UN Special Envoys to Yemen and Somalia and head of office for the UN Special Envoy for Syria, Stephanie Koury &ndash exploring their work making peace in the world&rsquos most volatile conflicts, with veteran BBC foreign correspondents Allan Little and Razia Iqbal interrogating headline speakers.
Meanwhile The New York Times&rsquo photo exhibition Hard Truths exposes the gripping reality of social and political upheavals from the ISIS-ravaged streets of Mosul and Iraq, to the vigilante-style war on drugs in Rodrigo Duterte&rsquos Philippines.
The Walled Garden will host an arts and music programme, with music, spoken word, exhibitions, sustainable produce and workshops.
Cycle rides with authors Peter Walker, Will Manners, and Kate Rawles, and foraging walks will also take place around the grounds.
Barbara Dickson will perform an enchanting series of songs from Scotland and beyond on the Saturday.
And the festival will feature Lisa Kristine&rsquos pioneering new exhibition Bound to Freedom, a call to action and a brutal expos&eacute of modern slavery.
Renowned composer Nigel Osborne will be joined by Syrian, Ossetian and Georgian musicians, and followed by San Ghanny, music for Palestine on Saturday and SOWhErTO Africa on Sunday.
Other highlights include a talk by critically acclaimed author Maya Jasanoff, while Columbian lawyer and activist Oscar Guardiola-Rivera will discuss peacebuilding in Northern Ireland.
And on the centenary of Muriel Spark&rsquos birth, her friend Alan Taylor will be interviewed by veteran BBC journalist Geoffrey Baskerville.
Meanwhile Yemeni photographer Thana Faroq will offer a workshop on the power of visual storytelling, with human rights activist and actor Pinar Aksu leading one the following afternoon entitled &lsquothe theatre of the oppressed.&rsquo The full Beyond Borders Scotland summer events programme and box office is available online at www.beyondbordersscotland
Ticket prices: Weekend pass &pound49. Day pass &pound26. Individual events &pound12. Walled garden only &pound12.Email info@beyondbordersscotland or call 0131 557 7775.

title: three-borders-towns-in-running-to-be-named-most-beautiful-in-scotland
story:
THREE Borders towns are in the running to be named the most beautiful in Scotland.
Melrose, Peebles and Kelso are among the 35 communities to be put forward for the accolade, set up by tourism website Hidden Scotland.
And Borderers can vote online for their favourite &ndash with the overall winner being announced on August 10.
A spokesperson for the competition said: "Scotland is home to over 7,000 charming, picturesque and historic towns and villages that each have their own individualities and offerings which make them so special in their own rights. Coastline communities with cute harbours, small villages tucked at the foot of crags, towns enclosed by lush fauna and flora &ndash Scotland has everything to offer.
"Everyone has a town or village that has a special place in their hearts, each with a valid reason why it&rsquos the best, so now is the time to crown the most beautiful. The contest aims to find the most charming and picturesque place in the country."
Also in the running are: Millport, Oban, Fort Augustus, Findhorn, Anstruther, Stonehaven, Pittenweem, Crieff, Kirkcudbright, St Monans, Rosemarkie, Ballatar, Pennan, Braemar, Applecross, Torridon, Killin, Cromarty, Portree, Plockton, Tobermory, Lanark, Forres, Crovie, Stromness, Portnahaven, Crail, Luss, Dunkeld, Broughty Ferry, Comrie and Pitlochry.
Jack Cairney, the Founder Hidden Scotland added: "I&rsquom excited to start our search for Scotland&rsquos most beautiful town or village.
"Our audience have picked some of the most charming and picturesque places you can visit in Scotland and it&rsquos a delight to be able to showcase some of these places."
To vote, visit: https://hiddenscotland.co/scotlands-most-beautiful-town/

title: earlston-high-street-roadworks-to-start-next-month
story:
THERE'S disruption ahead for drivers in Earlston as resurfacing works of the towns High Street get underway next month.
The works on the section of the A6105 road will take place from Wednesday, August 1 to Friday, August 10 for eight days, with the route fully open to traffic on Saturday and Sunday, August 4 and 5.
The project will be completed in stages, with phase one seeing a section of the eastern end of the High Street closed for three days from August 1-3, from 8.30am to 5pm each day.
Phase two will be carried out using a convoy system from Monday to Friday, August 6-10, from 8.30am to 5pm each day.
The official diversion for drivers will be via the A68, B6362, A697, A6089 and A6105 for eastbound, with the reverse route for westbound traffic.
Parking restrictions will also be in place on the High Street during the works from 8am to 5pm. Parking restrictions will apply where no waiting cones are in place.
Preparatory works are currently being carried out in advance of the resurfacing programme, with temporary traffic lights in place.
Staff will be on site during the works to assist traffic and deliveries will be accommodated where possible.
And this week, letters will be provided to households and businesses affected.
Bus services will also be affected from Wednesday to Friday, August 1-3, service 60 will divert from Earlston bus stance via the A68 to Lauder, B6362, A697 to Greenlaw.
Service 60 from Greenlaw to Earlston will follow the same diversion.
During this diversion a demand-responsive shuttle bus service will be provided by EAJ Robertson to connect with service 60 at both Earlston and Greenlaw for customers affected by the road closure. This can be booked by calling 01361 882340.
If you are connecting from a Borders Buses service 60, users are urged to contact EAJ Robertson in advance for journeys between Greenlaw and Earlston.
From August 6-10, a convoy system will be in place on the High Street that will result in the bus stance being closed to all services between 8.30am and 5pm. Alternative pick up/drop off points will be provided.
Service 51/52 will pick up on the A68 in both directions and will omit Earlston town centre.
Service 60 will pick up and drop off on the A68 and will travel through the roadworks but not serving any bus stops on the High Street until Earlston Primary School.
Borders Buses are advising passengers to expect delays on service 60 during the works.
Councillor Gordon Edgar, Scottish Borders Council&rsquos executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: &ldquoEarlston High Street is an important route not just for local residents and businesses but as the A6105 is one of the main roads from the west to the east through the Borders.
&ldquoThis resurfacing programme will vastly improve the road in Earlston, and with only a short-term daytime closure required.
&ldquoAll road users are asked to follow signed diversions during the three day closure, and allow themselves some extra journey time throughout the works.

title: group-is-chuffed-with-plans-for-railway-museum
story:
THE wheels are in motion to honour Peebles&rsquo historic railway by creating a museum in the town.
In recognition of the prosperity the railway brought to the community, members of the Peebles Community Trust (PCT) are hoping to transform the former weigh bridge, located in Edinburgh Road car park, to house the railway archive dating back to 1855.
The development of Peebles owes a great deal to the railway, which made its final stop in 1962. During this time there were three railway stations in Peebles &ndash one where Tesco now stands, which was then extended to create a line to Galashiels the second in Dean Park and the third on Caledonian Road, serving travel to the west and Glasgow.
The rail link not only encouraged thousands of visitors, with The Hydro having its own spur, but underpinned the huge expansion of the weaving industry by providing fast, cheap links to world markets.
Until now there has been little recognition of the influence of the railway on the development of Peebles and, while some evidence can still be found in the Viaduct Bridge over the River Tweed and the railway tunnel connecting the bridge to the town, much has been lost.
But now railway enthusiasts are steaming ahead with plans to establish a museum which will house artefacts and photographs of historic trains during their journeys through Peebles.
The PCT is now hoping to gauge if there is an appetite amongst the people of Peebles for the museum.
Further investigations will have to be carried out, as it is believed the building is owned by Scottish Borders Council.
If the railway museum is given the green light, funding will be sought for the renovation of the old railway building. PCT chairman Lawrie Hayworth said: &ldquoThis a really exciting project which can help us all have access to this important period in the town&rsquos history, a period of rapid local transformation akin to the wider impact we see today with global internet access.
&ldquoThis should also boost visitor numbers to Peebles and provide economic benefit to the town. It is important to safeguard our heritage for future generations, and recognise the influential role the railway has played over the years.
If you would like to be involved in the project, contact PCT co-coordinator Alex Wilson at admin@peeblescommunity.org

title: views-sought-on-ayton-housing-development
story:
VIEWS are being sought on a potential major housing development in Ayton.
Berwickshire Housing Association has unveiled plans for 49 brand new homes to be built to the south of Ayton Primary School.&nbsp
The new estate will be accessed from Summerhill Park, with a secondary access route coming off Lawfield Drive.&nbsp
A meeting with Ayton Community Council is being held on Tuesday, September 4 to present the designs to councillors, followed by a public consultation meeting during the week commencing September 17 at Ayton Primary School.&nbsp
Berwickshire Housing Association development manager Colin Young said: &ldquoWe&rsquove owned this site for over 20 years and we&rsquore delighted that it is finally moving forward and will bring much needed homes to Ayton.
&ldquoWe&rsquove carried out a master plan exercise with architects Smith Scott Mullen. This included public consultation, the results of which have been fed into the final design.
&ldquoThe planning application will be for the whole site, but Berwickshire Housing Association is only proposing the construction of 29 units in phase one. No date has been agreed for phase two, but this is likely to be some years in the future.
&ldquoThe proposed housing is a mix of house types and sizes aimed at meeting local demand as identified in the recent local housing needs assessment. The family housing will help support the local primary school and local amenities.
&ldquoThe range of properties proposed also takes account of existing Berwickshire Housing Association stock and aims to fill unmet demand by providing more housing choice for applicants in the Ayton area.
Previously, a preliminary public consultation event was held on Wednesday, June 27 to discuss the proposals.

title: kelso-woman-accused-of-being-involved-in-two-bust-ups
story:

title: scottish-borders-council-to-mark-merchant-navy-day
story:
SCOTTISH Borders Council is to host a special reception to honour the services of Merchant Navy personnel.
And Borderers who have previously or currently serve are being asked to come forward to attend the event.
Merchant Navy Day is held on September 3 every year to honour the brave men and women who kept Britain afloat during both World Wars, and also celebrate the importance of modern day merchant seafarers.
A civic reception will be held on the same day at Newtown St Boswells to mark the occasion.
Council convener, Councillor David Parker, said: &ldquoThe Merchant Navy was given its name 100 years ago at the end of World War I, with King George V acknowledging their efforts in providing supplies to Britain.
&ldquoWith this special anniversary, we felt it was appropriate to mark the efforts of our local personnel and would request any Borders seafarers to get in contact with us so we can invite you to the reception.
Any Merchant Navy personnel from the Borders wishing to go should email CorporateMgtSupport@scotborders.gov.uk or phone 01835 826571 or contact councillor Sandy Aitchison &ndash saitchison@scotborders.gov.uk. Spaces are limited, so an early response is recommended .

title: borders-man-accused-of-making-nuisance-999-call
story:

Kevin Ferguson is said to have made abusive and offensive remarks of a sexual nature to the call handler and&nbspchallenge police officers to fight.
The offence is alleged to have been committed at his Earl Street home on May 27.
The case was continued without plea at Jedburgh Sheriff Court until August 6.

title: watch-moment-scottish-borders-mum-is-struck-by-lightning-while-filming-in-galashiels
story:
A GALASHIELS mum feared she was going to die after being 'stuck by lightning'.
Tracey Kutluol captured the moment on her phone from a&nbspwindow when she was 'struck'&nbspat around 10pm on Thursday night.
In the video, which has had over 25,000 views since it was posted to Facebook, Tracey opens the window and says: "I think I'm going to get electrocuted."
Despite pleas from her children not to film with the window open, Tracey reassuring them&nbspsaying "It's fine" before being 'struck' just seconds later.
The mum-of-two&nbspcan then be heard saying: "I've just been struck by lightning, I've just got struck, my phone blew."
Following the video, Tracey took to Facebook, posting:&nbsp"Learned my lesson...don&rsquot play with nature."
She added: "Told them [her children] all to&nbspgo downstairs to my room while I switched everything off...no damage done just really shaken up."
And things could have been much worse if it wasn't for one thing.
"We&rsquore all ok thank goodness. [It] was the most scariest thing...think my new phone case saved me."
According to Ready.gov, the advice for what to do in a thunderstorm is:
When you receive a thunderstorm warning or hear thunder, go inside immediately.  
If indoors, avoid running water or using landline phones. Electricity can travel through plumbing and phone lines.  
Protect your property. Unplug appliances and other electric devices. Secure outside furniture.  
If boating or swimming, get to land and find a sturdy, grounded shelter or vehicle immediately.  
If necessary, take shelter in a car with a metal top and sides. Do not touch anything metal.

title: peebles-theatre-seeks-cash-from-common-good-fund
story:
PEEBLES&rsquo Eastgate theatre has appealed to the Common Good fund to help revamp its facilities.
The theatre wants to upgrade its auditorium, at an estimated cost of &pound410,000, the majority of which will be funded through grants and donations from members of the public.
The theatre is seeking funding from the Peebles Common Good fund in order to unlock grants from organisations which require around 10 per cent of &nbsptheir contribution to be matched by a third party.
The project has recently applied for two grants &ndash for &pound80,000 and &pound30,000 &ndash and needs to secure third party funding from the Common Good fund amounting to &pound8,600 and &pound3,000, respectively.
The &pound80,000 grant will come from WREN, a non-profit company which funds projects with money raised by the landfill tax, while the &pound30,000 grant will come from the Land Trust, a land management and greenspace charity.
According to the theatre&rsquos website, the aims of the Eastgate development project are &ldquoto increase access to, and participation in, the services and activities of the Eastgate Theatre by extending its capacity, physically and operationally, and by developing an expanded suite of facilities that can more effectively meet the needs and demands of the growing population of Peebles and surrounding areas, both now and for the future.
&ldquoThe main elements are expected to include enlarging the building&rsquos footprint reconfiguring the ground floor layout to create more caf&eacute and studio space upgrading the first floor auditorium by renewing the seating and improving sightlines enhancing backstage facilities and updating heating and lighting services throughout the building.
The development project is in a race against time to secure a large grant from Europe.
The theatre has been offered &pound150,000 by the programme, on the condition that it matches that funding with money from elsewhere, such as the WREN and Land Trust grants.
The Eastgate has raised a substantial part of the money, but is still &pound70,000 short of the amount needed for match funding.
The deadline for meeting this condition is August 30, meaning the Peebles Common Good fund sub-committee has been brought forward to Monday, in order to maximise the chances of securing the additional funding on time.
Caroline Adam, the theatre&rsquos general manager, said: &ldquoWe have been working on the development project for two years and today the first major step forward is in sight.
&ldquoFourteen years ago the Eastgate was created by the determination of the local community to realise the dream of having a space where all sorts of arts could flourish.
&ldquoToday performances in the theatre attract audiences of 21,000 a year and more than 40,000 people visit the Eastgate for other reasons.
&ldquoThis development will provide an excellent theatre space ready to meet future demand. We are very close but it won&rsquot happen at all unless we reach the &pound70,000 target with this final fundraising push.
The redevelopment will see all of the seating in the auditorium replaced or repositioned to increase space and improve the sightlines from the balconies, as well as installing new hand grabs on the aisle seats and improving the heating and ventilation systems.

title: biking-bonanza-coming-to-traquair
story:
VISITORS to the Beyond Borders International Festival at Traquair House next month will be able to take part in free guided bike rides.
Local resident Andrew Marchant will be teaming up with authors and avid cyclists Kate Rawles, Peter Walker and Will Manners to lead a series of rides through the local countryside.
Festival goers will be welcome to bring their own or simply hop on one of the hire bikes that will be available free of charge.
Along the stunning routes in the surrounding area, cyclists will listen and share a wealth of cycling knowledge with Andrew, Kate, Will and Peter. As well as giving informal talks, the authors will take part in a Beyond Borders Question Time panel discussion in the Walled Garden, discussing the positive impact that cycling can have on society.
Kate Rawles wrote &lsquoThe Carbon Cycle&rsquo about her 4553-mile ride across the ridge of the Rocky Mountains, from Texas to Alaska. She completed the entire journey on the UK&rsquos first bamboo bike, Woody, which she will be bringing with her to the Borders.
political correspondent Peter Walker is equally keen to get people out on their bikes. He curates &rsquos award-winning &lsquoBike Blog&rsquo and is author of &lsquoBike Nation: How Cycling Can Save The World&rsquo.
The impact of cycling on human history is a topic also close to the heart of Will Manners.
His book, &lsquoRevolution: How the Bicycle Reinvented Modern Britain&rsquo explores how the invention of the bicycle in the 19th Century contributed to human evolution, changing how people travelled, met each other and moved between isolated rural communities.
Will, Peter and Kate will be available for book signings and will each discuss their books as part of the Walled Garden programme.
Following its introduction to the festival in 2017, the Walled Garden is shaping up to be &ldquoan explosion of cultural activities according to Catherine Maxwell Stuart, 21st Lady of Traquair House, and includes prize-winning photography from The New York Times, music from Barbara Dickson, pop-up poetry and more.
The Beyond Borders festival takes place on August 25 and 26. A full programme and tickets are available online at www.beyondbordersscotland
Tickets
are &pound49 for a weekend pass &pound26 for a day pass &pound9 for individual events access to the Walled Garden only is &pound12 and the walks and cycle rides are &pound6.
For more information, email info@beyondbordersscotland or call 0131 557 7775.

title: borderers-have-a-chance-to-saddle-up-and-own-a-pony-for-a-day
story:
HORSE-LOVERS in the Borders are being given the chance to own a pony for the day.
Harestanes Countryside Visitors Centre, near Jedburgh, is hosting an event to give youngsters over the age of eight the opportunity to learn more about equestrian.
The event will be run by Eat Sleep Ride CIC, a registered community interest company, licensed riding school and trekking centre.
And after the previous success of Pony Ride Days, leisure trust Live Borders, which runs the venue, has decided to bring the programme back this year.
Harestanes manager, Michael Scott said: &ldquoOver the last couple of months we have had some fantastic numbers and feedback from our pony riding days so we decided during the holidays to provide a different programme for people looking to gain some experience in care and preparation of horses and ponies.
&ldquoWith the Own a Pony Days, participants will spend the whole day with the pony.
&ldquoWe have had plenty of interest in these two days so we are urging people to book their spots before they are all gone.
Participants will take their pony through grooming, plaiting, tacking up, leading, riding, games, obstacle course, lesson and a mini show.
There are 12 places available each day (two people per pony) and the minimum age is eight so that a child does not have to be accompanied by an adult.
Adults are also welcome to participate.
Participants are asked to bring appropriate clothing for all weather and a change of clothes. All safety equipment will be provided, but people are welcome to bring their own.
The event is runs on Tuesday, August 7 and Tuesday, August 14 from 10am-4pm.
The cost is &pound60 per person and that will include a packed caf&eacute lunch with a sandwich (ham, cheese or jam), packet of crisps, carton of juice or water, tray bake and fruit.
To reserve a place, call 01835 830306.
Booking forms can be found at www.liveborders .org.uk/Harestanes.

title: borders-tourist-info-centres-set-to-close-as-part-of-visitscotland-strategy
story:
TOURIST information centres across the Borders are set to close in the new year.
VisitScotland has announced radical plans which will leave Jedburgh the only town in the Borders with a dedicated Tourist Information Centre.
The move comes following a drastic drop in footfall at centres across the country - from seven million in 2005 to less than three million last year - and research which shows that two in three visitors access information online.
From next February the iCentre in Peebles will close.
And from this October the provision for providing tourism information in Hawick will be delivered by Live Borders.
Malcolm Roughead, chief executive of VisitScotland told us: "The way visitors access information has changed significantly and we need to reflect this by switching investment to new initiatives in order to reach more people with personalised information so they stay longer, spend more and grow the visitor economy.
&ldquoThe new two&ndashyear strategy (2017 to 2019) will see a significant increase in the number of channels providing content on places to visit and stay, with a mix of industry partners, Coo Vans and digital products sitting alongside 26 key iCentres in high impact locations.
The Borders branch closures come after the shutters came down at Melrose Tourist Information Centre last June following a move of location and a drop in visitor numbers.
And Kelso's TIC also closed for good last October.
VisitScotland's new strategy will see Jedburgh&rsquos iCentre being supported by over 70 VisitScotland Information Partners (VIPs) across, which includes hotels, bed &amp breakfasts, self-catering properties and camping sites.
Attractions such as Glentress, Abbotsford and Traquair House have also signed up as VIPs.
A VisitScotland spokeswoman added: "This new approach will allow the national tourism organisation to reflect changing visitor demands and deliver more personalised information through a diverse range of channels so people stay longer, spend more and help to grow the economy.
"VisitScotland staff have also been significantly mobilised over the past 18 months enabling knowledgeable advisors to deliver face to face information to every corner of Scotland at events and attractions.
"A fleet of Coo Vans hit the road each summer on a mission to inform the masses and in addition VisitScotland delivers outreach at major events with pop up information hubs.
"In the area the Coo Vans have visited Borders Book Festival in Melrose, Thirlestane Castle and Abbotsford House and will be visiting Floors Castle Pipe Band Day and Borders&rsquo Railway Steam Train Day providing advice and what to see and do in the region.
"In addition, an investment of almost &pound6000 in new signage for the Jedburgh iCentre will be put in place shortly."

title: galashiels-goes-extreme-with-town-centre-stunt-team
story:
EXPECT a few thrills and spills in Galashiels later this month as community leaders hit top gear.
Business group BID Galashiels has organised a day of high-octane fun in and around the town centre on Saturday, August 25.
And taking centre stage will be the dare-devil riders and skaters from Team Extreme.
On top of the professional stunt displays in Bank Street Gardens, there will be a seven-metre high climbing wall and a gladiator duel arena.
A live music stage will make sure the thrilling spectacle has the perfect soundtrack.
And for the energetic there will be Zumba and Spin Bike sessions with Live Borders.
Several buskers have also been booked to make sure the day goes with a swing.
Co-organiser Andrew Poole told the Border : "We're incredibly excited to be bringing a professional stunt team to Galashiels.
"This is a real first.
"Team Extreme perform daredevil stunts throwing themselves sometimes twenty foot into the air on their skateboards and BMX bikes.
"This alone promises to be an exciting spectacle to watch.
"Add into that the other attractions on the day with the climbing wall, the gladiator duel arena, a live music stage and demonstrations of Zumba and Spin Bikes, the whole day is shaping up to be something very unique for Galashiels and a whole lot of fun for everyone.
"And importantly, everything on the day is free."
The event is the latest venture from BID Galashiels in an effort to create improved trading and business for the town.
Andrew added: "BID For Galashiels is a business community led organisation seeking to establish a Business Improvement District for Galashiels town centre.
"Part of that project is to demonstrate to local businesses how we can improve footfall and visitors to the town.
"This event is just one example of how we may be able to do that on a more regular basis, if the business owners vote positively for a BID to be established when they are balloted in November this year."
The fun day will run from 11am until 4pm and will be supported by a live outside broadcast from Radio Borders.

title: last-blast-for-cheltenham-bound-selkirk-silver-band
story:
SELKIRK Silver Band is staging a special summer concert in the marquee at Haining House on Sunday, August 19.
It will be the band&rsquos final public appearance before it heads to Cheltenham for next month&rsquos UK national brass band championships.
&ldquoIt&rsquos a very exciting time for our members, said bandmaster Colin Kemp, &ldquoand naturally the band wants to do everyone in Selkirk proud when it plays at the national finals in September.
&ldquoWe receive tremendous support from the local community throughout the year, and this month&rsquos concert gives us the chance to show our appreciation for all the public&rsquos help and encouragement.
In recent weeks band members have been busy raising funds to enable them to make the trip to Cheltenham.
As well running a pop-up shop and hosting a stall at last month&rsquos farmers&rsquo market, a commemorative brochure has been produced charting the band&rsquos 121-year history.
The Haining concert will comprise a wide-ranging musical programme. Included will be a special arrangement of &ldquoThe Rowan Tree featuring a tenor horn solo by Les Mallin, as well as excerpts from the musical &ldquoOh What A Lovely War!.
The concert will run from 2pm to 5pm, and as well as a licensed bar, members of the public will be able to purchase afternoon teas.
Tickets
priced &pound7 (&pound5 conc.) are now on sale at McCudden&rsquos Newsagents in Selkirk High Street, or can be purchased from any band member.

title: disruption-expected-as-resurfacing-starts-on-earlston-high-street
story:
MOTORISTS in Earlston can expect disruption from tomorrow as a major resurfacing programme begins.
The works on the section of the A6105 road will take place for eight days from Wednesday, August 1, to Friday, August 10, with the route fully open on Saturday and Sunday.
Phase one will see a section of the eastern end of the High Street closed for three days from 8.30am to 5pm.
And phase two will be carried out using a convoy system from next Monday to Friday between 8.30am and 5pm.
The official diversion is via the A68, B6362, A697, A6089 and A6105 for eastbound, with the reverse route for westbound traffic.
Parking restrictions will also be in place on the High Street during the works from 8am to 5pm.
Councillor Gordon Edgar, Executive Member for Roads and Infrastructure, said: &ldquoEarlston High Street is an important route not just for local residents and businesses but as the A6105 is one of the main roads from the west to the east through the Borders.
&ldquoThis resurfacing programme will vastly improve the road in Earlston, and with only a short-term daytime closure required.
&ldquoAll road users are asked to follow signed diversions during the three day closure, and allow themselves some extra journey time throughout the works.
Bus services will also be disrupted during the works.
From tomorrow to Friday, service 60 will divert from Earlston bus stance via the A68 to Lauder, B6362, A697 to Greenlaw.
Service 60 from Greenlaw to Earlston will follow the same diversion.
During this diversion a demand-responsive shuttle bus service will be provided by EAJ Robertson to connect with service 60 at both Earlston and Greenlaw for customers affected by the road closure. This can be booked by calling 01361 882340. If you are connecting from a Borders Buses service 60, please contact EAJ Robertson in advance for journeys between Greenlaw and Earlston.
Next week a convoy system will be in place on the High Street that will result in the bus stance being closed to all services between 8.30am and 5pm.
Alternative pick up/drop off points will be provided.

title: woman-92-conned-out-of-five-figure-sum-by-bogus-workmen
story:
A 92-YEAR-OLD woman has been conned out of a five-figure sum by bogus workmen in Melrose.
The woman was visited at her home on at least three occasions by two men claiming to be from an Edinburgh masonry company between June 28 and July 17.
The pair advised the woman that they were carrying out work on the outer portion of her garden wall and over the course of the month were able to defraud her of a five-figure sum of cash.
A family member then contacted police after being made aware of these incidents and establishing that no work had been undertaken at the property.
The suspects are described only as white, in their forties and with skinny builds.
Inspector Bryan Burns from Melrose Police Station said: "These individuals have repeatedly targeted a vulnerable member of the Melrose community and were paid large sums of cash for work that was neither required in the first instance, nor carried out in any case.
"Anyone who believes they have information relevant to this investigation should contact police immediately.
"We would once again urge the public not to allow unsolicited callers to carry out any work or repairs on their properties. Only use trusted tradespeople, who you have contacted in advance.
"In addition, we would ask that our communities be wary of any suspicious activity around the homes of elderly or vulnerable friends, family and neighbours and report any concerns you may have to us.
"We have a range of really useful crime prevention advice available on our website at www.scotland.police.uk."
Those with information relating to this incident can contact Melrose Police Station via 101 and quote incident number 1540 of July 30.
Alternatively, an anonymous report can be made to the charity Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

title: facebook-finds-sophisticated-efforts-to-disrupt-elections
story:
Facebook set off a firestorm on Tuesday, announcing that it had uncovered &ldquosophisticated efforts, possibly linked to Russia, to manipulate US politics and by extension the upcoming midterm elections.
The company was careful to hedge its announcement it did not connect the effort directly to Russia or to the midterms, now less than a hundred days away.
Its findings were limited to 32 apparently fake accounts on Facebook and Instagram, which the company removed because they were involved in &ldquocoordinated and &ldquoinauthentic political behaviour.
But official Washington went ballistic anyway, not least because the reported activity so closely mirrored Russian influence efforts during the 2016 presidential election.
Nearly 300,000 people followed at least one of the newly banned accounts and thousands expressed interest in events they promoted.
Sharing an update on our work to remove bad actors on Facebook
https://t.co/yAn3zF21j4
&mdash Facebook (@facebook) 
July 31, 2018
&ldquoThis is an absolute attack on our democracy, said Virginia Senator Mark Warner, the top Democrat on the Senate intelligence committee and one of several politicians Facebook had briefed in advance.
He expressed &ldquopretty high confidence that Russia was behind the assault.
A spokesman for Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley said Facebook had informed his office that &ldquothat a limited group of Russian actors has attempted to spread disinformation using its platform and that the affected groups are affiliated with the political left.
The identified accounts sought to &ldquopromote divisions and set Americans against one another, wrote Ben Nimmo and Graham Brookie of the Atlantic Council&rsquos Digital Forensic Research Lab in a blog post Tuesday.
The non-profit is working with Facebook to find and analyse abuse on its service.
The perpetrators, Facebook noted, have been &ldquomore careful to cover their tracks than in 2016, in part because of steps Facebook has taken to prevent abuse over the past year.
For example, they used virtual private networks and internet phone services to mask their locations, and paid third parties to run ads on their behalf.
After it became clear that Russia-linked actors used social media to try to influence the 2016 US election, Facebook has escalated countermeasures intended to prevent a repeat.
It has cracked down on fake accounts and tried to slow the spread of fake news and misinformation through outside fact-checkers.
The company has also announced new guidelines around political advertisements, requiring disclosure of who paid for them and keeping a database.
I am glad to see that Facebook is taking a much-needed step toward limiting the use of their platform by foreign influence campaigns. The goal of these operations is to sow discord, distrust, and division. 
https://t.co/Fzwr1QFfG0
&mdash Richard Burr (@SenatorBurr) 
July 31, 2018
Facebook has ramped up spending on these and other measures, so much so that it finally spooked investors with a forecast of lower profitability last Wednesday.
Facebook&rsquos shares promptly dropped almost 20% and have not recovered.
While the company would not say who is behind the efforts, Facebook said it uncovered links between the accounts it just deleted and those created by Russia&rsquos Internet Research Agency in the 2016 influence effort.
For example, the Atlantic Council&rsquos researchers noted &ldquolanguage patterns that indicate non-native English and consistent mistranslation, as well as an overwhelming focus on polarising issues.
The accounts seemed focused on building up an online audience and moving it to offline events, such as protests.
The earliest page was created in March 2017.
Facebook said more than 290,000 accounts followed at least one of the fake pages.
The most followed Facebook pages had names such as &ldquoAztlan Warriors, Black Elevation, &ldquoMindful Being, and &ldquoResisters.
Facebook did not provide detailed descriptions of those pages. But their names parallel those of 2016 groups established by Russian agents to manipulate Americans with particular ethnic, cultural or political identities. That effort targeted people with both liberal and conservative leanings.
This time, though, the pages Facebook found focused &ldquoexclusively at engaging and influencing the left end of the American political spectrum, according to the Atlantic Council researchers.
Facebook says the pages ran about 150 ads for 11,000 dollars on Facebook and Instagram, paid for in US and Canadian dollars. The first ad was created in April 2017 the last was created in June 2018.
On a Tuesday conference call, Facebook executives declined to say much more, including whether the pages spanned a range of political opinion and whether the accounts mentioned specific candidates or politicians.
It&rsquos clear much more work needs to be done before the midterms to harden our defenses, because foreign bad actors are using the exact same playbook they used in 2016 &mdash dividing us along political and ideological lines.    
As Dan Coats said, the warning lights are blinking red. 
https://t.co/ifev077BHe
&mdash Adam Schiff (@RepAdamSchiff) 
July 31, 2018
California Representative Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House intelligence committee, said more work needs to be done before the midterm elections.
&ldquoForeign bad actors are using the exact same playbook they used in 2016, he said. They are &ldquodividing us along political and ideological lines, to the detriment of our cherished democratic system.
The intelligence panel is planning to hold a hearing in early September with Facebook chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg, Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey and an executive from Google.
President Donald Trump has offered mixed messages on Russian interference, at times even calling it a &ldquohoax.
After appearing to question whether the Russians would try again to interfere earlier this month, he acknowledged last week in a tweet that the midterms were a likely target. But he said that Democrats, not his fellow Republicans, would be the ones supported by Russia.
On Tuesday, White House spokesman Hogan Gidley said that Mr Trump &ldquohas made it clear his administration will not tolerate foreign interference in our electoral process from any nation state or other malicious actors.

title: american-bishop-who-preached-at-royal-wedding-has-surgery
story:
The American clergyman who preached about the power of love at the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex has undergone surgery for prostate cancer.
An Episcopal Church spokeswoman said the surgery was performed on Tuesday on the Most Rev Michael Curry.
The 65-year-old announced his cancer diagnosis last week and said he planned to have surgery to remove the prostate gland.
Rev Curry said he expected to spend four to six weeks recuperating. He said he would resume his duties as presiding bishop of the church in early September.
Rev Curry is the first black leader of the Episcopal Church in the United States.
His fiery sermon at the May 19 wedding of Harry and Meghan offered a contrast to the more solemn Anglican style that many guests were used to.
